title: English sans-serif of the 19th century
content:
Greetings typophiles!

Does anyone know of any sans-serif typefaces of the 19th century from England? It's rather specific, but hope many typographically-knowledged folk here would know of some.

Cheers all!
author: scarlettfu

comments.content: I think William Caslon IV's "Two Line Egyptian" is generally considered the first sans-serif... it's certainly English, and certainly 19th C. Uppercase only, AFAIK. I don't know where you might find an implementation, though (if you need one, that is).

Thank you very much! An implementation of it (or at least, a reinterpretation of it) may be required at a later stage. But currently, I'm gathering as much as I can. I've scoured the net and have only found a fair few.

The correct name is "two line English Egyption", BTW. [There's a sample halfway down this page.](http://web.archive.org/web/20150424022740/http:/www.csun.edu/~pjd77408/DrD/Art461/LecturesAll/Lectures/Type&PrintingHistory/IndustrialRevolution/TypographyInnovations.htm)

[Here is an implementation](http://web.archive.org/web/20150424022740/http:/cavedoni.com/2007/11/introducing-micerino.pdf). This is a link to a pdf. I was unable to navigate to anywhere else on Cavedoni's website.  
 - Herb
